results.title: Primary media studies
results.creator_credit: Stephen Skok, Film Media Studies and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Indicates various types of activities that could be included in a primary media studies course. Shows hand drawing on film, making storyboards, exercises in persistence of vision, stimuli for creative writing, drama with video and script development.

results.title: Making your mind up

results.title: That's one of my talents
results.brief_description: This program aims to provide school leavers with information about a range of non-traditional occupations and working styles. It shows specific examples of both “alternative” money-generating activities and life style options currently being undertaken by Victorians.

results.title: Discus
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Coaching and Training for Track and Field Events”.
Gives coaching tips for discus events from Olympic athletes and coaches, plus footage of discus events from the Moscow Olympics.

results.title: Computers in Agriculture
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Living with Computers”.
Expert, Dr David White, talks about the use of computers in agriculture - a paper presented to the Junior World Congress, Melbourne, October 1980.

results.title: All is well on the border front
results.creator_credit: Akram Zaatari, Future Television and Lebanon Theater
results.brief_description: A tribute to Godard’s seminal “Ici et Ailleurs” (Here and Elsewhere), video artist Akram Zaatari’s documentary, like its predecessor, critically explores issues of representation within the occupied zone of South Lebanon. Interviews with Lebanese prisoners in Israel illustrate aspects of life under occupation with convincing poignancy. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Akram Zaatari, Future Television and Lebanon Theater

results.title: Pandemonium
results.creator_credit: Haydn Keenan, KFM Pandemonium, Smart Street Films and Tra La La Films
results.brief_description: Haydn Keenan’s “Pandemonium” is a schlock horror movie that aims to displease by entertaining themes of Neo-Nazism, torture, vampirism, incest, sado-masochism, mental illness, necrophilia and bestiality. In the opening sequence Kales Leadingham has escaped from a lunatic asylum. Arriving at a bus stop be relays his travails (in flashback) to a woman seated there. One day at Bondi Beach, Sydney, a woman ‘Dingo Girl’ arrives in search of answers to her past (cue unremitting shots of Dingo Girl’s large breasts, a la Russ Meyer). Shortly after Dingo Girl and Kale enter a warehouse where a bizarre array of subversive types reside. Inhabitants engage in ritualistic Neo-Nazi ceremonies that result in sado-masochistic sex. Amid other activities, a foetus is placed in a blender, Little Adolph has his penis cut off, cloning experiments go awry - whilst numerous musical interludes interrupt the action. Deliberately provocative, and seeking to shock, this film revels in its low-budget amateurism and artlessness. Aesthetically it shares much in common with “Flesh for Frankenstein” and “Rocky Horror Picture Show” but has no hope of achieving the cult status of these enduring films, principally because its relentlessly over-the-top mood and delivery rob it of any impact as comedy or as horror. The unremitting black humour, shoddy sets, trashy costuming, bad taste themes and poor acting, make “Pandemonium” a curio of Australian filmmaking. Cast includes David Argue, Amanda Dole, Esben Storm, Ian Nimmo, Gary Foley, Haydn Keenan, Ignatius Jones, Lex Marinos.

results.title: The Circle = Dayereh = Il Cerchio [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi, Jafar Panahi Film Productions, Lumière & Co. and Mikado Film Srl (Rome)
results.brief_description: From Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi (The White balloon), comes The Circle” a tale of female oppression in modern day Iran. “The Circle opens in a hospital maternity ward where a woman has just given birth. Her mother is horrified by the catastrophic outcome - its a girl. She had been assured (via ultrasound) that it would be a boy and laments the fact that a divorce will ensue and her daughter will be shamed. This opening sequence reflects the status of women in Iran, as unwanted, second-class citizens without rights or a voice in society. “The Circle” tells the stories of several women in a city over the course of one day and night. Simple acts of buying a bus ticket or smoking a cigarette in public are denied to women and are punishable by law. The women of the film, in constant danger of imprisonment and harassment, are shunned by their families and seek refuge with each other. Panahi adopts a documentary style for this feature film, as street noise fills the soundtrack and the camera follows the characters around, almost hounding them. “The Circle” was banned in Iran due to its controversial subject matter. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Golden Lion, Best Film at the 2000 Venice Film Festival)
